title: Research support | Library | University of Bristol
content:
Research Support

Open research

Open Research is a broad range of research practices which, when combined, makes research more accessible, transparent, reproducible, and visible. The Library's

Research Support Team

provides training, advice and support on a range of Open Research topics.

Open Access publishing

Open Access is free, unrestricted online access to research outputs. The Open Access team offers help and advice to University of Bristol researchers who need or want to publish their research by open access methods.

Research data management

Research data management involves the organisation and preservation of research data and is a core area of research integrity. The Research Data Service supports University of Bristol researchers in planning, creating, using and sharing research data.

SafePod

Get secure local access to sensitive datasets via the University's SafePod, located in the Medical Library.

Submission of theses to the library

The University of Bristol requires students to submit their thesis electronically. The option is also open to current members of staff who completed their thesis at the University of Bristol.

Copyright enquiries

The Research Support team handles enquiries relating to University of Bristol research. This might relate to journal articles, datasets or code produced by University of Bristol academics or students.

Researcher metrics

Use citation metrics (bibliometrics) and alternative metrics to benchmark your research performance, find collaborators, and decide where to publish. The Library Research Support team can help you select appropriate metrics, access analysis tools, and interpret metrics data.

Digital Scholarship Support

At Bristol,

Digital Scholarship

involves using digital tools alongside unique historical collections to support research and teaching. The

Library Digital Scholarship

team includes both support staff and academics, working closely with archivists across the University to help get the most out of unique cultural collections.

Literature and systematic review

The Subject Support Team are experts in resources for their subjects and will be able to help you with a comprehensive review of the literature. They can provide advice and support on:

Key databases to search

Building a search strategy

Using advanced search techniques

Setting up search alerts

Other sources including 'grey literature'

Further reading and

systematic review training courses

.

Subject specific systematic review guides are available for

Health Sciences

and

Social Sciences

. The Subject Support Team can also assist with managing search results and provide training and support around reference management software. Please visit their

EndNote

,

Zotero

and

Mendeley

support pages for more information.

Contact details for members of the Subject Support Team can be found

on

your Subject Guide

.

Fitness class descriptions

Virtual classes

BODYCOMBAT

Step into a BODYCOMBAT workout and you’ll punch and kick your way to fitness, you may burn up to 740 calories along the way. This high-energy martial-arts inspired workout is totally non-contact and there are no complex moves to master. A LES MILLS™ instructor will challenge you to up the intensity and motivate you to make the most of every round. You’ll release stress, have a blast and feel like a champ.

GRIT™

GRIT™ is a

30-minute

high-intensity interval training (HIIT) workout, designed to improve strength and build lean muscle.

SPRINT

™

A 30-minute high-intensity interval training (HIIT) workout, using an indoor bike to achieve fast results.

THE TRIP™

THE TRIP

™

is

a fully immersive workout experience that combines a 40-minute multi-peak cycling workout with a journey through

digitally created

worlds.

Instructor-led classes

Aerobics

A cardio-based class which combines a variety of high impact exercises to raise your heart rate and improve your overall fitness. A lower impact section of the class will help improve overall muscle tone.

Asthanga

relaxation

techniques

this session

Using light to moderate weights and a small step this class offers a low impact total body workout suitable for every level of fitness.

Beginners Hatha Flow Yoga

A class for everyone! Brand new to yoga? Looking to refresh your practice? Returning after injury or illness? In this class we explore the four cornerstones of yoga practice, Breath, Postures, Relaxation & Philosophy, taught in a relaxed and practical way with a lot of guidance & support.

BODYBALANCE™

BODYBALANCE™ is a Yoga, Tai Chi and Pilates inspired workout that builds flexibility and strength. Focusing on controlled breathing, mindful practice and a carefully structured series of stretches and poses to music creates a holistic workout that brings the body into a state of harmony and balance.

BODYCOMBAT

A non-contact, high-energy martial arts inspired workout. There are no complex moves to master - you’ll punch and kick your way to fitness!

Body Conditioning

A low impact full-body workout which uses dumbells to build strength and tone in a fun and friendly way. The weights you use can be chosen based on your own ability.

BODYPUMP™

BODYPUMP™ barbell classes will sculpt, tone and strengthen your whole body! Focusing on low weight loads and high repetition movements, gain strength, endurance and lean body muscle.

Bootcamp

A high intensity class using a variety of equipment and bodyweight exercises to get you fitter and stronger than ever before. Get ready to sweat and be pushed to your limits with a combo of HITT (high intensity interval training), circuits and drills.

Breath-flow Yoga

This class is an exploration of mind, body and breath. Invite curiosity to the living ecology of you, through moving the body and sensing the grooves of the mind. Expect to learn the use of breath and posture, to release tension and develop your awareness.

Circuits

Circuit training is a full-body workout that will improve your athletic power and aerobic fitness. Working against the clock, you will work your way around a number of stations, featuring a wide range of weighted, equipment-based exercises.

Linking yoga postures in a flowing sequence. Excellent for building CV fitness, muscular endurance, balance, flexibility, mobility, stability for core and all major

muscles

group.

Creates balanced lean and strong muscles around the abdominals hips and back. Focusing on any postural imbalances, increasing muscular strength, flexibility and overall well being. Suitable for all levels as options are given.

This structured and progressive class of bursts of fat burning, sweat producing and heart pumping effort for 30 seconds (HIT), followed up with Pilates

exercises

that teach good posture and form. It is a fast, fun, challenging but safe workout designed to help you build fitness, strength, core stability and lose weight.

HIIT Workout

A 30-minute high-intensity interval training (HIIT) class. Get ready to punch, kick, run and jump your way to an endorphin high. All abilities are welcome, exercise options will be given throughout.

Crazy Core is a class designed for everyone, starting from beginners to advanced.  If you would love to build core muscles and improve posture whilst enjoying fancy lights and energetic music this is the class for you. An energetic breath-led yoga flow suitable for all levels. Steps offered to guide you toward more advanced postures.

Boost your cardiovascular fitness in this 45-minute workout on a static bike. No previous experience or skill needed - just bring good energy! Spinning takes you through a varied cycle journey building endurance, speed and recovery powers.

Stretch

A class to help you stretch out your entire

bod

y

muscle by muscle and leave you feeling re-aligned and loose!

A session designed to improve everyday performance by lengthening,

stretching

and toning the muscles. This classic mat Pilates class works the core and mind by focusing on realignments and improving posture.

A class concentrating on working the muscles of the abdominals and back using a large inflatable ball. This class will help improve your balance, muscular strength and full-body flexibility.

With the use of different postures, breathing, and relaxion techniques, this session will help to realign the

y

Helping you gain more self-confidence & self-awareness, to enable better choices emotionally, mentally and physically. We gently explore the full practice of yoga, Breath, Postures, Relaxation & Philosophy with much guidance & support.

Yogalates is a freestyle combination of the gentle stretch and mindfulness of Fitness Yoga and the core strength building

an

d

posture awareness of Pilates.

Zumba Fitness® is one of the fastest-growing, dance-based fitness phenomenons. Step-by-step, easy-to-follow dance moves with full-body fitness benefits.

Community exercise

Community Exercise is a supported exercise programme for residents of our local community.  It offers guided classes and social sessions particularly suited for those with any health or mobility issues.

On this page

Memberships

Before you join

Class descriptions

View the Community Exercise class timetable

With different classes from Monday to Friday every week, find the session for you.

Memberships

Annual - £219.25

Monthly - £26*

*Monthly memberships have a joining fee of £26 and a 2-month minimum term.

There are 3 separate payment method options for your new Community Exercise membership:

Monthly direct debit

, giving you the more flexibility with your payments

Purchased annually

, which offers you an annual saving equal to 3 months membership vs paying monthly

Pay as you go (PAYG)

which allows you to access individual sessions for a cost of £6 per session.

Active Community member benefits

Save time and money - with unlimited access to the Community Exercise class programme (the more you go, the more you save!). An Active Community membership eliminates the need to purchase PAYG sessions at the Welcome desk.

Earlier booking rights - members can book classes more than 1 week ahead. PAYG visitors may only book onto a session from 7 days in advance, if there is still space.

Before you join

All new members will receive a complimentary health assessment, which is essential to undertake as part of their joining process. The health assessment will be undertaken in-person at the Indoor Sports Centre, with a member of our Health & Fitness team. There are 3 steps to join;

Complete the

Community Exercise Health Statement form

. You can print this and return it to our reception desk at the Indoor Sports Centre, or email it to us at

sports-members-admin@bristol.ac.uk

.

Once your Health Statement form has been received, a member of our team will get in touch with you to arrange your in-person health assessment.

Following completion of the health assessment, our Memberships team will be able to finalise your membership and the corresponding payment arrangements.

Existing members - health assessment

Existing members do not need to undertake a health assessment at the point of membership renewal, however the service is available, should you wish to book one. We advise that you do undertake a health assessment if there has been a change in your medical circumstances during your membership term.

The health assessment for existing members costs £36.75, minus your usual member discount (e.g. 10% for our public community).

title: Fitness workshops and group sessions | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Fitness workshops and group sessions

Bookable group fitness sessions allow individuals to try new exercises in an inclusive environment, and ask questions from our qualified gym team.

Quiet Fitness Hours

We've partnered with the Bristol University Neurodiversity Network (BUNS) to introduce sensory-inclusive Quiet Hours at our gym.

These are bookable sessions, open to all, are designed to create a more comfortable environment for those with neurodiverse conditions or hidden disabilities by reducing sensory stimuli.

During these sessions, there will be no music playing, only essential tannoy announcements, and reduced gym capacity to minimize crowding. Staff will be proactively supporting facility users.

We ask that all gym users be mindful during these times, respecting personal space and keeping noise to a minimum, to support the goals of these sessions.

Mondays:

9 am to 11 am

Wednesdays:

8 pm to 10 pm

Gym for women and those who identify as women

The Indoor Sports Centre gym hosts two gym sessions for women and those who identify as women.

These are bookable sessions that provide full access to our gym for self-identifying females. The sessions will be overseen by mixed gender staff. Advance booking is mandatory.

Included within these sessions, a demonstration area will be reserved for individuals to come over and ask questions, try new exercises, improve technique, or just simply watch and learn.

Wednesdays:

2:15 pm to 3:15 pm

Fridays:

10:30 am to 11:30 am

The Studio Gym

The Studio Gym is our new workout space designed to provide an environment for those who find the main gym areas to be overwhelming at times. You will find a range of equipment to provide most exercise options except heavy lifting forms.

The space is pre-bookable, on the hour, in 50-min slots (capacity 8 per session) through our mobile app, and is available during usual gym opening hours (except when used for S.E.H group sessions).

Book a session

Fitness workshops and group sessions can be booked

online

or

via the Active app

.

Non-members who meet the specified criteria for the session are welcome to join! You can book on a

pay-as-you-go

basis.

Important information for all gym users:

Please be aware that these sessions are incredibly popular and can often exceed capacity, so early booking is recommended.

Only those users who have booked and received confirmation of their booking may attend these sessions.

This means that all non-booked users will need to vacate the gym space before the session starts

, and can return or enter into the gym only once the session has ended.

Please note: last entry for general gym usage is 30-minutes before the start of the bookable session. Users will be asked to vacate the gym 10 minutes before these sessions start, to allow booked members timely access.

title: Climate Action Plan | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Climate Action Plan

Sport, Exercise and Health Climate Action Plan sets out the specific carbon reduction activities that the division is taking to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions.

Why do we have a Climate Action Plan?

We are facing a global climate and biodiversity emergency. The natural ecosystems we depend

upon are under significant and substantial threat and we are already witnessing the

consequences of climate change.

This Climate Action Plan is the divisions contributions to a net-zero carbon campus.

What is a Climate Action Plan (CAP)?​

Sport, Exercise and Health (SEH) Climate Action Plan (CAP) sets out the specific carbon reduction activities that

the division is taking to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions.

​

SEH CAP Co-Ordinator is Gordon

Aitken

and he Chairs a CAP coordinating group responsible for generating the

divisions Plan. It is reviewed on an ongoing basis by both the Sustainability Department and the University's

Sustainability Implementation and Monitoring Board.  For more information on the University aims to go carbon netural, read their

8 point carbon plan

.

content:
Sports Medicine Clinic

The clinicians at the Sports Medicine Clinic offer expert and comprehensive sports medicine services to all, whether you are a student, a member of staff at the University or a member of the wider public community. Our clinicians stay at the forefront of treatment and research and adhere to high professional standards.

On this page

Services

Open Clinic

Book an appointment

here at the Sports Medicine Clinic. Find out more about each service and meet our clinicians below.

From 1 October 2025, clients receiving physiotherapy and osteopathy treatment are invited to utilise complimentary gym access (for a limited period) alongside their treatment, where identified as appropriate by their clinician.

Physiotherapy

Physiotherapy is a science-based profession, promoting recovery from an injury, illness or disability. Physiotherapists use movement and exercise, manual therapy, education and advice to ease pain and maintain or improve movement.

A

ppointments available: Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

Meet our clinicians:

Henry Abrahams

Emma Hurst

Osteopathy

Osteopathic treatment is largely hands-on, and may include stretching of shortened soft tissues, specific massage techniques, rhythmic joint mobilisations and joint manipulation.

Appointments available: Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.

Meet our clinician:

Gerry Gallacher

Massage & Sports Massage

Massage is a manual technique used to manipulate soft tissues (muscles, ligaments, tendons) to relieve pain, reduce tension, improve circulation, and promote relaxation. Our therapists are able to provide a range of treatment. Deep tissue massage addresses chronic muscle tension and pain, whereas sports massage is more focused on improving athletic performance, treating sports injuries, and increasing flexibility. In addition, we provide tailored treatments, such as neck/shoulder massage and lower-body runners’ massage.

ppointments available: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

Meet our clinicians:

Paul Reay

content:
Swimming pool

The University swimming pool has six lanes and a moveable bulkhead, creating a competition-length main pool, alongside a comfortable teaching pool for lessons. The pool is available to students, staff and the community for lane and casual swimming, or lessons, on a membership or pay-as-you-go basis.

View the term 1 swimming pool timetable

From 1 September to 21 December 2025. Lane swim sessions are available 7 days a week.

View the winter break swimming pool timetable

From 22 December 2025 to 4 January 2026.

Interested in swimming lessons?

About the pool

The University of Bristol swimming pool is 32 metres long at full length. The pool has a moveable bulkhead which enables us to create two distinct area for activity; a larger area is a 25-metre competition length swimming pool, and a smaller teaching pool for lessons and casual swimming.

During lane swimming sessions, the main pool is split into six lanes. Casual swim sessions will feaure one narrow lane in the main pool, and swimmers in this session will also have access to the smaller teaching pool.

The depth of the pool ranges from 1.2 metres at its most shallow point to 3.8 metres at the deep end.

Accessibility

owever

gender neutral

changing

space

.

ny of our designated changing facilities.

We offer a range of

swimming lessons and courses

which follow the Swim England swim stages, including adult swimming lessons. We also offer various aquatic sport activities for juniors and teens. If you are bringing a child to the pool for a lesson or course, please read our

guidance for parents and guardians

.

You can access the pool for casual or lane swimming sessions with one of our flexible

membership

options or on a

pay-as-you-go

basis.

University of Bristol students and staff non-members benefit from discounted pay-as-you-go prices.

Mission Inflatable

Take on the

Mission Inflatable

for the ultimate children’s pool activity. Have fun, play and race each other on the inflatable course during one of our bookable sessions.

University of Bristol students and staff are eligible for free swimming during their pregnancy.

Download and return our

application form

to

sports-members-admin@bristol.ac.uk

along with a scanned copy of your NHS prescription exemption card as proof of eligibility. No membership is required.

Hire the pool

The pool is available to

sports clubs

and community groups for commercial hire.

Contact our bookings team

for availability.

Health and safety guidelines

All participants must be able to swim 25 metres unaided.

Please ensure a 1:1 adult-to-child ratio for children under 4 years.

Please ensure a 1:2 adult-to-child ratio for children age 5 to 7 years.

Babies must wear leak-proof swim pants.

All swimmers must shower thoroughly before entering the pool.

We recommend not swimming within 48-hours of having any sickness.

Please inform lifeguards of any medical conditions before entering the pool.

ue

Guidance for parents/guardians

Important information for parents and guardians of children attending swimming lessons and courses.

Adult Swimming Lessons

Adult Beginner

Beginners is about gaining confidence to be safe in the water. It also teaches the ability to move around the pool and achieve the basic core aquatic skills. Including entries, exits, buoyancy, balance and aquatic breathing. Building up to swimming independently over short distances (5 to 10 metres). Group ratio 1:5. Lessons take place in the teaching area depth 1.2-1.5m

Adult Improver

By this point you’ll be able to swim independently, the focus of these group lessons are to improve stroke technique for Frontcrawl, Backstroke and Breaststroke. Building confidence to swim distance 100m. Group ratio 1:6. Lessons take place in the teaching area depth 1.2-1.5m

Adult Improver Plus

Lesson takes place in a lane in the 25m main pool. Group ratio 1:6. Aiming to build stamina over longer distances and stroke technique. Introducing aquatic skills such as streamline, diving and turns.

title: Pay and Play | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Pay & Play

Members and non-members can experience the range of activities the University of Bristol offers through our Pay & Play programmes. There’s more information and detail on how to book an indoor or outdoor court below.

Adult group coaching indoors at Coombe Dingle

These popular coach-led sessions are based around a weekly theme. They're good fun and a great workout! They cost £16 per session (when played indoors) and £13 per session (when played outdoors).

Coach & Play - Tuesday, 9:30 am to 11:00 am

Tuesday morning is for players who can comfortably play singles/doubles matches. Players will have the opportunity to play with a number of people throughout the session and receive personalised feedback, to help improve their game.

Inclusive Tennis

If you

use a wheelchair or if you would like to play tennis in a wheelchair, you would be very welcome to come along to our weekly wheelchair tennis session - The Wheely Good Tennis Club. The

weekly session is

indoors,

great fun, a chance to learn more about the game, make friends and get some individual feedback about your game from Dom, our Coach, who has been working with the group for over three years.

The

group includes children and adults and Dom designs sessions around the feedback from the group

. All equipment is

provided,

including sports chairs, but you’re welcome to bring your own if you have one.

Please

contact us

if you would like more information and / or if you would like to join our WGTC WhatsApp Group (

18+ so parents of juniors and adult participants only).

The session takes places on Saturday at 1 pm to 2 pm and cost £5 per player, per session.

Barclays Local Tennis Leagues

Over 200 mixed singles and doubles leagues are taking place at local parks and public courts across the nation all year round for adults over the age of 18, and you can get involved.  Whether you are a beginner or advanced, you will have the opportunity to meet new people, power up your game and compete at a park court near you.

View upcoming rounds, sign up deadlines and more on the

LTA's website.

1:1 Coaching

Are you interested in tennis coaching? We have a number of LTA qualified coaches that you can book for 1:1 tennis lessons. For individual coach prices and contact details to book, follow onto our

Meet the Team

page.

Book a court

Members and non-members can book a court to play tennis at Coombe Dingle Sports Complex. Indoor and outdoor courts can be booked

on the University of Bristol Active app (which is free to download).

Please note, certain

memberships

give access to free or discounted tennis court hire.

Prices

Indoor

£22.00 per court, per hour

Outdoor

£7.90 per court, per hour

Please note that only University of Bristol Tennis Coaches are permitted to hire courts for the purpose of coaching tennis.

Anyone found to be coaching without approval from the Director of Tennis will be asked to leave. This is to protect the integrity of our coaching offer and to ensure we are meeting our safeguarding obligations.

How to book a session

Login to your account

with you student details

Click 'Make a booking'

Select 'Coombe Dingle'

Click 'Tennis Activities'

Click 'Coach and Play'

Click 'View Timetable'

Select the date you wish to book

Please note that bookings can only be made 8 days in advance.

title: UOB Student Programme | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Student Programmes

As a student of the University of Bristol there are many ways to start or continue your tennis journey, whether it is in the form of attending free classes, joining our student club or developing your skills through coaching.

B:Active

B:Active is a programme of social fitness and sport sessions, exclusively for University of Bristol students. Our wide range of sessions are all completely free, suitable for all abilities. Tennis-based activities on the timetable range from Cardio Tennis, to Pickleball to Tennis Skills.

Sessions run at Wills, Coombe Dingle and at the Indoor Sports Centre on Tyndall Avenue, to make the sport as accessible as possible.

All of

the B:Active tennis (and Pickleball) sessions are run by UOB students with coaching qualifications and experience, and supported by student Activators. It is

a great way

to start playing regularly, or to supplement your weekly tennis programme.

Find a session here!

UBTC

The

University of Bristol Tennis Club (UBTC)

is one of the largest University Tennis Clubs in the UK with over 500 members, run by students, for students. They are a large, friendly society, filled with students whose time at University has been greatly enhanced by being involved in the club, playing tennis as well as creating lifelong friendships. There is something for everyone on court and the UBTC committee works hard to put on numerous social events throughout the season and focus on the wellbeing of their members.

The UBTC committee and coaching team

provide

opportunities for

all abilities (from beginner to BUCS and everything in between). UBTC is powered by UOB student volunteers and supported by the UOB Tennis T

eam

and you are welcome to get involved at any point during the academic year.

To find out more about the range of memberships available, how to get involved and their upcoming events, visit

the

club website

.

Performance Tennis

We are

very proud

of the offer for our performance tennis players at Bristol. We have a programme that provides an inspiring and supportive environment for all our team players to improve with a more bespoke individualised offer for our Maroon Scholars.

Our Head Coach, Ali Blackett, works closely with our BUCS Captains and players throughout the year to make sure that they have everything they need on and off the court to reach their potential.

If you are considering applying to the University of Bristol and have competed for your county, region or country please email

ali.blackett@bristol.ac.uk

who will be able to provide you with more information or the opportunity to book in a Zoom meeting to get to know our programme better.

Scholarships

We have a limited number of scholarships available for high-performance athletes including the

Vice-Chancellor scholarship

and the new

University of Bristol Maroon scholarship

. For more information please get in touch with our

Performance Team

.

Get Involved

We strive

to support University of Bristol students who have an interest in developing through tennis. We

provide

support for students looking to

complete LTA coaching qualifications and we also look for students who are interested in creating,

running

and developing competitions across the programme. We

are able to

provide funding, 1:1 support, work experience and mentors, paid work (for those who apply / are approved by the Director of Tennis)

and opportunities with partner venues and the LTA throughout the season.

If you would like to find out more about upcoming opportunities (LTA Level 1, 2 and 3 qualifications, LTA Competition Organiser and LTA Basic Referee courses) please email our University Tennis Coordinator Ollie Bendall

ollie.bendall@bristol.ac.uk

.

title: BUCS UNIversal | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
BUCS UNIversal scheme

What is the BUCS UNIversal pass?

UNIversal Gym passes open the doors to multiple gyms around the country, meaning you can work out wherever you are in the UK, helping staff and students stay active all year round.

This means if you have a gym membership at your university gym of study or work and it's part of the network,  you will have access to many more gyms around the country at no extra cost.

So, when you are exploring the country with friends or visiting back home, you can access other university gyms near you to keep you active.

Who is eligible?

All University of Bristol students and staff who take out a 12 month paid-in-full or Bursary single one-off payment

Active Complete membership

are entitled to free access to 70+ university gyms via the BUCS UNIversal scheme.

How to apply (University of Bristol students)

Log in or register for a

BUCS account

.

Search for BUCS UNIversal Gym

Select 'University of Bristol'

Send an approval request by 19 December 2025

Once approved you can book gym sessions at any participating university.

How to apply (non-University of Bristol students)

Log in or register for a

BUCS account

.

Search for BUCS UNIversal Gym

Select the university at which you study

Send an approval request by 19 December 2025

Once approved you can book gym sessions at any participating university.

How do I find out which gyms I can visit using my BUCS UNIversal pass?

Visit the

BUCS UNIversal website

for a full list of participating facilities.

The scheme runs from 29 September 2025 to 27 September 2026. This is a fixed period, regardless of the date you start your membership.

Excludes access to/students at UWE due to location.

Members should check their guest facility for any additional terms in place, such as specific access hours for BUCS UNIversal visitors.

Terms and Conditions

.

Please read the information about our

process.

title: Membership FAQs | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Membership FAQs

Find answers to your most frequently asked questions about memberships at the University of Bristol.

If the information provided below is not able to answer your enquiry, please get in touch with our membership team via our

enquiry form

.

How do I cancel my membership?

Monthly memberships:

If you pay monthly for your membership,

contact us

with a cancellation request in writing.

You must give notice to cancel your membership 10 working days (or more) before the end of the month for payments to stop immediately. If you cancel within the last 10 working days of any given month, the payment will have already been processed and the following month will be paid for in full. In this instance, your membership will remain active until the end of the following month and you will still be able to access facilities.

Annual memberships:

If you pay annually, you are unable to cancel your membership part-way through your membership term unless you provide a medical certificate to show that you are unable to continue to safely use the facilities.

Our cancellation policy is outlined in our

terms and conditions

(Section 5).

Please note:

if you decide to rejoin at a later date, normal joining fees will apply.

Why can't I renew my membership online?

If you do not renew your membership before the expiry date, your membership account 'lapses' and will need to be reactivated by our memberships team before you can purchase a new membership online.

Contact us via our

online enquiry form

.

Why won't the gates at reception open?

The gates at reception will not open if either:

you do not have a valid membership -

purchase a membership or pay-as-you-go pass

online.

OR

you have not made a booking for the activity currently in session - many of our activities need to be

booked

online in advance.

Gates will also refuse access if:

you have an outstanding balance on your account

you have not completed a gym induction

you have a strike ban on your account (if you are given 3 strikes on your account you will be unable to make session bookings for 6 days)

Why can't I make a booking through my account?

If you are unable to make a booking it is because, either:

the class is fully booked - our classes are are popular, however at times people do cancel a booking which will create spaces for others. You can join the waiting list and you will be automatically added if a space becomes available for you, up to 3 hours before the booking start-time - make sure to check your online account.

OR

you do no have fitness class benefits included in your membership - you can attend classes on a

pay-as-you-go

basis, or

upgrade your membership

online at any time

OR

you have a bookings ban on your account - a bookings ban is imposed when you incur 3 strikes on your account.

Strikes are added to your account if:

you fail to attend a booking

you attend a booking late

you fail to swipe you card to confirm attendance

you cancel a booking within 3-hours of the booking start time.

A bookings ban will last for one week. This system has been put in place to stop people booking multiple classes in advance and not attending.

If none of these apply to you and you are still experiencing problems,

contact our memberships team

.

I receive a bursary - do I get a discounted membership?

Yes.

Get in touch

with your student number and we will be able to tell you which membership discounts apply to you.

Please note that all Bursary memberships expire on 31 August each academic year.

REDs Awards

The Bristol RED is one of the most prestigious sporting awards conferred by the University along with the Director's Award and the Inclusivity and Wellbeing Award.

On this page

What are the REDs Awards?

Award categories

Celebrating our previous winners

What are the REDs Awards?

The REDs Award Ceremony give us the opportunity to recognise the achievements of our student athletes at Bristol.

A Bristol RED and a Director's Award are the two of most prestigious sporting awards conferred by the University. Eligible students will have given outstanding performances on and off the pitch in their respective sports. Their achievements will place them at the pinnacle of their sport during their time at university.

Previous winners have gone on to achieve national and international recognition, winning Rugby World Cups and Olympic gold medals.

Award categories

Bristol RED Award

Awarded to students who have achieved success in representative sport, beyond University level.

Bristol Director's Award

Awarded to students who have made a significant contribution to their clubs on and off field as well as having played at a consistently high level.

'We Are Bristol' Inclusivity Award

Awarded to a student, team or club that has pro-actively achieved a more inclusive environment and encouraged more members to participate, especially from under-represented groups. This could be in terms of competition, training, or social engagement.

'We Are Bristol' Wellbeing Award

Awarded to a student, team or club that has executed a project or idea with clear aims to improve the mental health and wellbeing of club members and the #WeAreBristol community.

content:
Scholarships

The University of Bristol is committed to supporting the dual-career journey of student athletes who are aspiring to or are currently competing at international level.

Apply for a sports scholarship

Applications for 2026/27 scholarships are open until 11:59 am on 1 March 2026. We look forward to hearing from you!

Our Sport Scholarship offer

Our Vice-Chancellor's (VC) Scholars for Sport are an inspirational group who train and compete as part of our student clubs, whilst also driving towards professional or elite athletic careers on the world stage during their time at the University of Bristol.

Scholarships for Sport are valued at £1,552 per student, per annum for each year of your course (though this is reviewed annually). The support package that all Scholars receive as part of the programme equates to approximately £6,000 in services each year.

Scholars are coached by a multi-disciplinary team of performance sport experts whilst on the programme and receive an excellent Performance benefits package which supports our athletes mentally, physically and financially throughout their tenure on the programme, including extra skills sessions, 1 to 1 nutrition, sport psychology, physio and

strength and conditioning (S&C)

support.

Applications are welcomed by all sports and athletes who feel that they fulfil the criteria of Performance, with a particular interest in applicants competing in the following sports. This is where we have Head Coach and Co-Ordinator members of staff.

Boat

Cricket

Football

Hockey

Netball

Rugby

Tennis

Why apply for a Scholarship at Bristol?

The University of Bristol Performance Sport offer has grown and developed dramatically over the past five years.

Bristol has consistently performed as a Top-10 University in the BUCS League table since 2016/17. We also compete on a National Level in many sports as well.

Bristol is a Dual Career Accredited Centre in partnership with

TASS (Talented Athlete Scholarship Scheme)

Bristol has a prestigious Alumni Sporting

Hall of Fame

, featuring Olympians, Commonwealth Gold Medalists, and GB representation across a range of sports.

We provide a competitive but holistic scholarship programme for student-athletes, comprising both sport and lifestyle coaching, mentoring and support. Bristol is the true model of a Dual-Career environment.

Talented athletes at Bristol continue to excel in their sport, whilst also performing and achieving academically, throughout their time as a student

Through partnerships with National Governing Bodies (NGBs) and Professional Sports Clubs locally and nationally, Bristol offers development opportunities for our Student Athletes to achieve outside of the university environment

We have a dedicated team of Performance and Pathway staff who want to speak to you and see how your life as a Bristol Sporting Scholar could work.

Eligibility and applications

Applicants must be entering their first year of study at Bristol.

University of Bristol must be your first-choice university with UCAS in order to be eligible for a Scholarship.

Applicants should be able to demonstrate a clear Commonwealth, Olympic and/or professional representational pathway.

Junior or Senior level representation and interest to progress.

You must choose only one sport in your application.

For more information about the Vice-Chancellor's scholarship and other scholarships offered by the University of Bristol, eligibility criteria and terms, application dates and additional guidance, visit the

University's Student Finance Scholarships page

. This form is separate to your UCAS application.

title: Performance Staff | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Performance Staff

Performance Manager

Matt Paine

Matt delivers our programme of Performance which covers a remit of Scholar Athletes, Clubs, and leads our team of  Coaches and MDT staff who support all of the programmes and delivery. Over the last 10 years Matt has led the University into the BUCS Top 10 in 8 consecutive seasons, and created an environment where true Dual Careers can take place. The University has had many Olympic, Commonwealth, Professional and International representation success stories in his time and Matt is very proud of the USP that supports both academic and sporting excellence. Matt has a degree in Sports Science and Business and a Masters in Leadership in Sport from Loughborough. Through his creativity and challenging processes he demands that Performance Sport at Bristol continues to evolve and progress.

Strength and Conditioning

Will Ruscombe-King, S&C Lead

Will is responsible for identifying and recruiting high level athletes for the University's performance programme, and is committed to building an inspiring education and transformative student experience. As our full-time Lead Strength & Conditioning Coach, and having coached sports like football, field hockey and rugby since the age of 16, Will continues to help our performance clubs with S&C on a part-time basis, alongside his pathway management work. Will initially found his interest in S&C while studying his undergraduate degree at Cardiff Metropolitan University.

Ethan Preddy, S&C Coach for Rugby

Ethan leads the rugby performance programme, working closely with both men’s and women’s squads to drive physical development and on-pitch performance. Alongside this, he provides support for other performance clubs, including netball and football programmes, contributing to a multi-sport performance environment. His wider experience includes time with Bristol Bears Rugby, Bristol City Academy, and the All Blacks Sevens programme, as well as performance roles within multiple boarding schools across the UK and internationally, supporting athletes across a broad range of sports and competitive levels. Like Will, Ethan also found his passion for S&C at Cardiff Metropolitan University at both undergraduate and postgraduate levels.

Gary Pepperell, S&C Coach

Gary leads the provision of S&C to our cricket, hockey and tennis programs aiming to reduce the likelihood of injury, increase availability and optimise performance. Alongside this, he also provides S&C support to other performance teams including basketball, football and other select programs.

Gary also works as “Athletic Development Coach” at Bristol Grammar School and enjoys the synergy of both roles where he develops long term athletic development one end and optimises performance and in university athletes the other. Gary’s previous experience is gained from working as S&C lead for the Canadian Sports Institute – Atlantic and the University of New Brunswick where he aided athletes sporting successes at major games and sports competitions.

Gary has been coaching since the commencement and completion of both his undergraduate and postgraduate degrees at the University of Gloucestershire and thrives watching athletes success at all levels.

Head Coaches

Olly Slym, Head of Rugby

Level 3 RFU coach has been in the club for a number of years as the Club Manager before getting the role the 22/23 season. Olly played a good level as a youngster before leaving the sport following some serious injuries. Olly comes with a back ground in coaching, mentoring, business and fundraising which fit nicely into his role at University of Bristol.
Ollys aim is to ensure UBRFC has the best student experience in the country whilst pushing the club to play in the highest league possible. When not at Coombe Dingle Olly can be found coaching local sides, academies and schools across the region.

Chris White, Hockey

Chris is our Head of Hockey here at Bristol. His role is to support and run the hockey programme for both men and ladies clubs. He comes from a great hockey background working at a lot of different schools around the UK but has also taken some time to coach hockey abroad in New Zealand, America, Holland. His passion for the game will continue the develop the hockey here at Bristol and keep them competing at the highest level. Chris is an ambitious coach and already enjoying his development at Bristol.

Edward Bloomfield, Rowing

Ed joined the University of Bristol Boat Club (UBBC) in 2015 as our Development Coach and progressed quickly to Head Coach. Having started coaching at St Edwards School Oxford, he swiftly took up a project with the women's squad. His work has brought the standard of Bristol Women's Rowing up to a new height, culminating in a record 4th place in the Championship 8+ at BUCS Regatta 2018. Ed is well placed to continue developing our club programme, aiming to develop talented individuals from all squads into robust and successful athletes who can compete nationally and internationally.

Ali Blackett, Tennis

LTA Level 4 Senior Performance Coach, Ali brings a wealth of experience of working with young people to her role as Head coach of University of Bristol Tennis (UBTC). Ali's drive and passion is to make Tennis at the University one of the leading clubs offering Tennis to all levels from social tennis to BUCS competitive players of a very high standard (LTA ranking 7.2 or higher).

Amber Reed, Women Rugby

Amber joined the staff team in summer 2024, following the signing of a partnership agreement between the University and Bristol Bears. During Amber's professional rugby career, she won a World Cup and Grand Slams with England Rugby, and Captained Bristol Bears Women.

Coaches and Coordinators

Chris Bolton, Cricket Coach

With over 10 years of coaching experience, Chris is our UBCC Head Coach. Having made his ECB Premier League debut at the age of 17, Chris finished school and went to play overseas cricket in Cape Town. On returning to the UK, he was awarded a Cricket Scholarship in 2014 to be a part of Bournemouth University’s High Performance Programme, where he won the BUCS Southern Prem, National Cup Runners Up and National Indoor finalists. In 2017, Chris was awarded an additional Academic Scholarship including funding to complete his MSc research in South-East Asia. Chris is currently still playing West of England Premier League cricket; he also holds an ECB Advanced Coaching qualification and works alongside UBCC on Gloucestershire CCC’s Talent Pathway U18s.

Martin Hicks, Hockey Talent Academy Lead

Martin joined Bristol in 2021. Martin brings over 10 years of coaching experience at varying levels and ages in club, county and England Hockey Performance Centre roles. Martin is currently undertaking the GB Hockey ‘Advanced Coach Programme’ alongside his part time role with Bristol and his 'other' professional career. Martin is a dedicated and enthusiastic coach, driven by a passion for developing people inside and outside of sport. Martin aims to support hockey at Bristol to take the next step forward at all levels.

Alan Tyers, Men's Football Coordinator

Men's Football Coordinator with over 20 years of coaching in BUCS and has a level 3 coaching award from the FA. Alan has a wealth of experience of coaching and managing teams at varying levels and ages of football. He is passionate about developing University players and seeing them progress through the various levels within the university football club. He is keen to forge links with local teams in order to widen the experiences of the football cohort.

Chantelle Wopara, Netball Coordinator

Netball Club Coordinator, Chantelle Wopara, brings over 13 years of experience coaching university netball. Chantelle has experience of playing at National and Super League Level and is currently Team Bath Superleague Assistant coach. Chantelle’s ambition and passion is to make sure netball at the university is available to all, from those who want to play socially all the way through to the elite.

Multi-Disciplinary Team

Connor Grant, Sports Psychologist

Connor is a BASES Supervised Sport Scientist (Psychology), Certified Mental Toughness Consultant and LTA Level 3 tennis coach. He has been fortunate to work with a wide range of sporting individuals and teams, from 'weekend warriors’ to Olympic gold medalists. His passion for both people and human performance has seen him ply his trade in Africa, Europe and Australasia. Now back in Bristol, he is adding value and insight to the University’s Performance Programme, Maroon scholars and BUCS Squads.

Henry Abrahams, Sports Physiotherapy

Physiotherapist (MSc) and a Personal Trainer (National Academy of Sports Medicine) with a BSc in Sports Science. Henry is passionate about health and fitness and the physiological and psychological benefits of regular exercise, movement and nutrition. As part of his role at the Sports Medicine Clinic, Henry works closely with the University of Bristol Performance Squad athletes and the Strength and Conditioning team.

Will Armour, Sports Nutritionist

Will is a Sport Nutritionist with an MSc Distinction and SENR Graduate Registration, experienced in supporting athletes across a range of sports. His previous work includes delivering season-long nutrition support to the Bristol All Golds Rugby League Club as a GetPRO Grant winner and completing his MSc dissertation tracking an ultra-endurance athlete through competition. Passionate about food and athlete development, Will specialises in tailoring evidence-based nutritional strategies to individual performance needs. At the University of Bristol, he delivers education sessions to performance squads and provides one-to-one support to Scholars, helping them balance university life with the demands of high-performance sport.

content:
Talent Academy - About Us

Everything you need to know our club vision, values and aspirations.

Jump to:

A note about our club founder, Ben Dudley

Summary of 2023-24 season

Our Values and Behaviours

Our Ethos and Vision

Strategy

England Hockey Statement

A note about our club founder Ben Dudley

Ben was the

much loved

Head of Hockey at the University of Bristol, until he tragically lost his

6 year

battle with blood cancer in 2023, aged just 36.

Ben joined Bristol in 2017, having also played and coached at junior international level, played in the Euro Hockey

League

and coached in the English Premier Division. Ben was a hugely passionate,

enthusiastic

and energetic coach. Despite illness Ben worked tirelessly to take hockey to the next level, principally within our Hockey Club but also in our Bristol community.

Ben worked tirelessly to develop players, coaches and the game as a whole.

Ben was the driving force behind everything at Bristol Hockey in the last six years and our guiding hand in the setting up of this Talent Academy. Ben had a vision of creating something bigger, something special to support the best (young) people and our game of hockey in this area. He

said

‘we can compete to be the best of

average

but we can work together to be the best

’.

We will continue to work towards Ben’s vision.

‌

Summary of 2023-24 season

Our first season as a Talent Academy has proven to be an enlightening, inspiring experience for everyone involved, from parents to coaches and most importantly for our awesome young people.

At the beginning of the 2023-24 season, we worked on a baseline of connections and in and out of possession principles and went into greater detail in Term 2 establishing our key tactical approaches and role expectations. In term 3 we refined our processes and refined our technical practices alongside the majority of our competitive games.

In term 3 we also added in some off-field coaching to support development of the ‘rounded-person’. These were

Strength and Conditioning

(Sports) Psychology

Nutrition (for Performance)

Our matches have proven to be a demonstration of the work we have put in throughout these hours, with both boys' and girls' groups putting in excellent performances, demonstrating teamwork, work ethic, determination as well as skill, leading to an excellent set of results.

In the 2024 Talent Academy Cup, the end of cycle competition; the squads put in some excellent performances and took full advantage of the 4 days to immerse themselves in tournament hockey, the girls squad performing particularly brilliantly, winning all 3 ‘pool’ matches to reach the ‘A’ finals. Ultimately it was not to be after a 1-1 draw and we lost to a sudden-death shootout to Surbiton. Nevertheless this cannot take anything from an incredible achievement and a superb year for our squads.‌

Our Values and Behaviours

B

rilliant -

We will be creative and try things without fear. We will be accountable for our behaviours. We are what we demonstrate.

R

esilient - We will believe in ourselves and our ability to perform and develop. We will be about the process not the outcome.

I

ntelligent - We will look for solutions to problems the game presents. We will get out head up and interpret what we are seeing.

S

elfless - We will be a good teammate. We will contribute our skills, abilities and intelligence to the team and work together to find solutions.

T

enacious - We will work harder than anyone and take accountability for our development. We will never give up.

O

ptimistic - We will have fun, enjoy the process of development and where it is going to lead us as people.

L

eaders - We will demonstrate and develop our ability to lead, in our own style and approach.

Our Ethos and Vision

T

he

University of Bristol is synonymous with aspiration, learning,

growth

and achievement. Bristol is one of the most popular and successful universities in the UK, ranked 61st in the world in the QS World University Rankings 2023.

As a Top 10 University for Performance Sport in the UK, we have a dedicated team of coaches and support staff to help our students train, compete and achieve their full sporting potential. Our Performance Squad

represents

our most-talented athletes who are combining sporting excellence with their studies.

The University of Bristol Hockey Talent Academy aims to

utilise

the excellence, ambition and standing of the University of Bristol and its passionate, people-focused coaches to develop and support the

most high

potential, aspiring young people in the area.

Strategy

O

ur

#

WEAREBRISTOL

hashtag

demonstrates

our ambition beyond university life. We want to be an

organisation

that can

represent

Bristol, that the city can be proud of.

The University of Bristol Talent Academy (TA) shall

seek

to play a major part in the Bristol hockey community working together to develop and support the widest range of young people in hockey in the area that we are able to reach and connect with.

Through the Talent Academy we aim:

To

operate

a person-

centred

, supportive fun yet challenging, hockey environment focused on players rounded physical, psychological, social and emotional education.

To marry the best aspects from our coaching experience in England Hockey Performance Centre environments, with the ideas and the thrust of our University Performance Sport environment.

To

utilise

the Club’s standing and ambition in the England Hockey structure to connect high potential young people with the some of the best hockey players in our area.

To further diversify our membership beyond our student population, keeping EDI and the principles of the Right Athlete Right Environment at the heart of our approach.

To offer young people a taste of life in a

University

performance sport environment.

England Hockey Statement

Talent Academies are intended for the highest potential 15 to 18-year-old players, replacing Performance Centres.

England Hockey estimate that the current talent pool will yield approximately 500 players per gender, requiring the intensity and commitment of a Talent Academy. This equates to the top 60% of players who currently attend Performance Centres, plus those who are part of England Age Group squads.

There will be multiple opportunities most weeks for high-quality coaching and training through a combination of dedicated sessions and integration with other activities delivered by the host. Every Talent Academy will have a squad of players selected through a robust process based on the England Hockey Player Profile.

Further information can be found on the

Talent Academy

page on the England Hockey website.

content:
Talent Academy - How to get involved

Information about the annual nomination, assessment and selection process for the University of Bristol Hockey Talent Academy.

The Talent Academy is for high-potential players aged between 15 to 18 years old (school years 10, 11, 12 and 13).

Each year, a squad of 25 young females and 25 young males are selected to be part of the Talent Academy through a nomination, assessment and selection process.

In addition to the squad of full-time players, the programme may have additional players who, due to individual circumstances, can attend on a less than weekly basis. Our Talent Academy Lead Coach will work with the player on this basis, to understand what is right for those individual's circumstances.

The Talent Academy player identification and selection process will serve two purposes.

To identify players for the following annual cycle (October to July), through a range of activities.

To identify players for the current annual cycle, where space allows.

Identification Stage (November - May)

Talent Academies will select players from a defined catchment area through a flexible process with pr

imary routes through local clubs,

schools

and County Hockey. There are multiple ways for a player to be initially

identified

.

Identification Stage - Talent Academy Festivals

The

Talent Academy may run festivals for school and club players in its catchment area to

provide

opportu

nities for players to be

identified

. Festivals present

a great opportunity

to frame events as

‘

developmental opportunities

’

rather than be labelled as an

‘

assessment

’

.

If a player is

identified

via a festival, and of the right age for either the current or

next annual cycle, the Talent Academy will encourage the player

’

s coach/teacher to complete the nomination process in order that they can attend a future open assessment day.

Identification Stage - Open Assessment Events

Players may be nominated to attend an open assessment event

at any point. These events will be communicated by Talent Academies to local clubs, schools and County Hockey coaches and administrators, via the

England Hockey website

. Coaches and administrators will use a

standardised

nomination form to recommend player

s.

The annual deadline for coaches to nomi

nate players for an open assessment event day is 1

st

May. Talent Academies must deliver all planned open assessment events by the end of the summer half term window, or no later than the

10th

June.

Observation Stage (January – May)

After a player has been

i

dentified

via an open assessment, they are invited to attend a series of observation sessions at their Talent Academy, between January - May.

Selection Stage (September)

Players successfully

identified

during the identification stage and, where possible

, the observation stage, will form a longlist along with existing eligible players within the Talent Academy

.

From the longlist, the Talent Academy coaches will undertake further assessments each September, with the final squads selected by the end o

f September each year.

The Talent Academy

programme

runs on an annual basis and players are typically selected for the whole cycle. If spaces become available during the cycle, for example due to withdrawals or injury, then

new players

may be added via the

above process.

Current TA players, who remain age eligible for the 2024-25 cycle, and are already accessing provision at a

neighbouring

TA will be made aware of

our

Bristol TA and the

option

to transfer. However, if these players are happy and wish to continue provision where they currently are, they may continue to do so. It is paramount our young players are happy and are accessing the right environment for them

, per the Right Athlete Right Environment

(

RARE

)

Principal

. All Talent Academies within the region have agreed to support this necessity.

Players accessing Open Assessment events at a neighbouring Talent Academy

Players who have recently been nominated and have, or are about to, access an open assessment event at a

neighbouring

Academy, will be made aware that the Bristol Talent Academy is

an option

.

Those players who wish to transfer to an open assessment with us, will

be able to do so in September.

Players who have not yet been nominated

The University of Bristol Talent Academy will run a series of open assessment events in September, to select a squad of circa 25 boys and 25 girls by the end of that month. Club, school

and junior County Hockey coaches across the region will be able to nominate players via the

title: Academy - Programme Overview | Sport, Exercise and Health | University of Bristol
content:
Talent Academy Programme

Programme Overview

Venue and Facilities

The Talent Academy training sessions and home fixtures are held at

Coombe

Dingle Sports Complex

Sports Complex, which is the main sports hub at the University of Bristol.

The site includes two floodlit, sand dressed astroturf hockey pitches, changing rooms and toilets.

Video/in-person classroom sessions will take place in the Main Pavilion at Coombe Dingle Sports Complex. This is configurable for a classroom environment and includes necessary WIFI & AV equipment.

Strength and conditioning sessions will take place in the OWL gym at Coombe Dingle Sports Complex.

There is free car parking available on site.

Training Programme

The Talent Academy runs throughout the season from October to July.

Training provision includes 260 delivery hours (130 hours per gender) of training/competition provision.

Training provision consists of a mix of on-pitch coaching, video/in-person classroom sessions, as well as sports psychology and strength and conditioning coaching.

This approach is considerate of the amount of Hockey Talent Academy athletes will be undertaking within the traditional hockey season (September to March) with school, club and Talent Academy Hockey. In the off-season (April to July), Talent Academy loading will increase as other hockey loading (club/school) is reduced.

Loading will be continuously reviewed throughout the cycle and adjustments made as the Talent Academy operation progresses, with the young people we work with foremost in mind. Additionally, short breaks during the season have been included to allow for rest in the schedule, for example a break scheduled during half term.

Session Timings

Talent Academy training sessions take place on Thursdays at Coombe Dingle Sports Complex.

The boys and girls' squad have one training session per week, held at either 6.30 pm - 8 pm or 8 pm - 9.30 pm. The training session times alternate between the boys and girls each week.

W

here

appropriate

, we can supplement delivery hours through attendance at UBHC sessions. A member of UBHC will have access to a further 2 x 1.5 hour club training sessions per week in terms 1 to 2 plus pre-season, thus adding potential for c.80 hours of training plus up to 22 games per season.

Competition Provision

Competition dates shall be in line with the England Hockey centralised calendar, of which we have set ‘reserved’ 15 competition days which includes the Talent Academy Festival in July (3 days).

These dates will be published to the squad via the Talent Academy monthly newsletter and posted on the Talent Academy Teamo account.

Membership and Costs

The cost of the Talent Academy is £899 per year payable via monthly direct debit through our

SEH portal

.

With this cost, Talent Academy athletes will participate in 260 hours (130 per gender) of hockey delivery hours.

For full details relating to payment of the programme please see our Sport, Exercise and Health

Terms and Conditions

with Section 1 Clause 4 and 5 covering payments and cancellation respectively.

Club Hockey Pathway

Athletes attending the Talent Academy shall not be required to

represent

the University of Bristol Hockey Club (UBHC)

.

The hockey club and Talent Academy entities will be separated but connected with the aim that young

people

feel supported

and

not pressed when it comes to choosing their hockey environments. However, where

appropriate

(

and subject to discussion)

, the

pathway

for young people to join UBHC will be available as it is today.

UBHC shall remain student-

centred

, allowing the Bristol Hockey Talent Academy to act ‘independently’ of a club, allowing young players and their parents a ‘clearer

’,

simpler choice when choosing to work with us, focused

around

their development and what is right for them.

Players shall not be required to ‘leave’ their home clubs and may continue to partake in junior and senior hockey within those environments. Players aspiring to higher levels of hockey where this does not exist within their home clubs may be offered this wit

h

UBHC or may be supported to find the right level of hockey within other positive coaching environments.

Club Purpose and Aspirations

The University of Bristol Hockey Club (UBHC) is one of the University

’

s largest and most successful clubs. With

nearly 400

members and 13 teams (7 Ladies,

6 Men

’

s), there is an environment for everyone who

wants to play hockey during their time at Bristol. UBHC consistently ranks in the Top 10 University hockey clubs in the country.

UBHC has gone from strength to strength in recent years, attracting high quality people, players and coaches. There are

a number of

professional coaches in place, led by our Head Coach who oversees both Men

’

s & Ladi

es’

pr

ogrammes

.

Our University of Bristol

Mens

1st team plays in the England Hockey Conference West, with a

n

ambition to return to Division One experienced in the 2022/23 season. Our Women’s 1st team is an ambitious West Premier League (W) team, having had two recent stints in

England

Hockey Conference West.

UBHC already has

a track record

of supporting some of our area

’

s highest potential young players, already working with schools and clubs to

provide

stretch, a challenging but welcoming environment and a focus on personal development, irrespective of

whether or not

a young person plays for the club.

Two of the current England U18 squad and one current England U16 have trained or played with the squad in the last 5 years. The club is currently supporting a total of 4 members, male and female, who would nominally be eligible for Talent Academy selection, who have chosen to play for the club. In

addition

the club continues to welcome other young people into training sessions on an ad-hoc basis where

appropriate

.

Right Athlete Right Environment

As coaches, we exist to support those we work

with

and our connections

provide

us

the energy to

provide

more opportunity

.

Through the Talent Academy, we are looking to

provide

more opportunity for young players in the Bristol area to train and play at a high

standard within the area and in an environment that truly supports their

interests above all

.

Talent Academy - Meet the team

Find out about the Talent Academy coaching team and committee.

Our Talent Academy Coaches

Chris White - Head Coach

Chris has joined the University coaching staff following 9 months in Japan and Australia. Prior to this Chris was the Hockey and Cricket Coach at Kings Bruton, where he was also a student, under the tutelage of Ben Dudley. Chris also played for the University of Bristol Mens Hockey Club as a non student player in our England Hockey league team, thus Chris already has a long association with Bristol and has already played a big part in the work that has been put in place by Ben.

Martin Hicks - Lead Coach (Girls)

Martin joined Bristol in August 2021 and acts as a Coach within the University Performance Hockey Programme, across both Mens and Ladies Squads. Martin has been part of the Coaching team for the University of Bristol Mens 1st team in their first season in England Hockey Division One (South) for the 2022/23 Campaign alongside leading the 2nd XI and supporting the University of Bristol Ladies 1st and 2nd XI’s. Prior to joining Bristol, Martin has almost 10 years coaching experience at various levels and age groups.

Duncan Armsby - Assistant Coach (Boys)

Duncan brings more than 18 years of successful coaching at club and school hockey with local club Westberries Ladies Hockey Club and Redmaids' High Girls School, as well as experience of working with Avon County boys U16 and U17 age groups. Duncan has recently completed his GB Hockey Advanced Coach Programme accreditation and also brings his extensive experience as a teacher to our team. Duncan will work primarily with the boys programme for this season.

George Nicholls - Assistant Coach (Girls)

Having grown up in Bristol, George has recently been through the  Bristol Performance Centre, DiSE and Futures Cup process himself prior to attending and graduating Birmingham University with a BSc in Sport and Exercise Science. George has captained and coached teams from a young age with Avon County and with TBB and continued this whilst at University of Birmingham; playing and Captaining his National league team alongside coaching and acting as Club Chairman. George has recently taken up coaching roles at Clifton College and Clifton Robinsons HC. George will work with the girls programme.

Our Committee

Chris White - Head of Hockey

Martin Hicks - Talent Academy Lead Coach (Girls)

Hannah Hicks - Talent Academy Manager and Welfare Officer

Amanda Richardson (maternity cover for Emma Ascott) - Talent Academy Administrator

anagement

be responsible for

all aspects of the Talent Academy in line with the vision and purpose (outlined on

About us

page), with a particular focus on the Welfare and development of participants.

The Talent Academy Management Committee shall

be responsible for

creating the culture to support individuals in line with the University of Bristol, the University of Bristol Hockey

Club

and the Bristol Hockey Talent Academy vision and principles.

Meetings will take place six times per year.

The University of Bristol has chosen individuals according to their skills and experience in running successful hockey

programmes

at the University of Bristol, in school, in clubs and in Junior Academy environments. The Talent Academy Lead Coaches have

significant experience

in the

previous

England Hockey Talent Systems.

(Voluntary) Independent Talent Academy Committee members have been appointed according to experience in other Talent Development environments with the aim of

maintaining

independence from the

organisation

and day to day leadership team with the ability to challenge processes and delivery where

appropriate

.

The Dispute process shall be undertaken through the Talent Academy Management Committee Chaired by the Talent Academy Lead. For any disputes involving the Talent Academy Lead, investigations and meetings shall be Chaired by the University of Bristol Head Coach and

or

an

England

TASS at the University of Bristol

The Talented Athlete Scholarship Scheme (

TASS

) is an athlete support programme to help talented athletes with balancing the demands of their sport and studies to be the best in both.

Backed by

Sport England

, the TASS partnership brings together student-athletes, education institutions and sports to support our country’s most exciting young talents.

Each year, hundreds of student-athletes benefit from a programme of support services delivered by experienced practitioners at education institutions across England.

TASS is dedicated to developing its network of performance sport experts and continues to lead the way in providing lifestyle and wellbeing support for athletes in education.

In 2018-19, more than 600 talented athletes from 32 different sports had benefited from support services at one of 33 TASS Delivery Sites.

The University of Bristol is proud to be a TASS Delivery Site this year. The support services available to TASS athletes at Bristol include:

Lifestyle

Physiotherapy

Strength and conditioning

Personal development (nutrition, psychology, further lifestyle)

TASS Medical Scheme & Bupa Healthy Minds

For more information on TASS or to find out how to access support, please visit the

title: Student noticeboards | Current students | University of Bristol
content:
Student noticeboards

Noticeboards specifically for student use have been installed in the Arts and Social Sciences Library, the Senate House Study Centre, and the Hawthorns Refectory.

These ‘spaces’ will be student-managed, meaning that you, along with your fellow students, will be responsible for posting and removing material, for respecting the material displayed by other students (meaning don’t deface, post over or remove posters that are not yours unless they are obviously out of date) and generally for looking after the space.

Poster guidance

The preferred size is A4 (or smaller); nothing larger than A3 please, and be aware that larger posters may be removed if space is tight.

One poster per site.

Posters should be affixed with drawing pins, which will be available at the noticeboard locations.

Posters displayed on other walls or places (eg easels or white boards) within the Arts and Social Sciences Library, Senate House Study Centre and Hawthorns Refectory will be removed.

Please no commercial material, and see the small print below.

The small print

Upon accepting your offer of a place to study, you will have agreed to the University’s rules and regulations, which were established to help create a positive environment for learning and academic achievement. Your relationship with the University carries with it the expectation that you will abide by the University policies on

Equality and Diversity

and

Acceptable behaviour

.

Most of this is common sense, but please be aware that the University reserves the right to remove any material that can be construed as defamatory, discriminatory, or otherwise offensive. If inappropriate material continues to be posted, and we are unable to identify the responsible party, the privilege of having this student-managed space will be removed. The ultimate decision as to whether a poster is or isn’t removed rests with the University.

title: Student led catering | Current students | University of Bristol
content:
Catering for student led events

When booking catering for your event, please make sure you follow the below process. Only approved suppliers may be used. This is applicable to all student-led events taking place across the University estate.

If you are organising catering for an event in your school, you must have:

a valid budget code

and

approval for your event from a budget holder. An approved budget holder within your school will need to place the order for you.

The University works with

approved third-party caterers

. They have gone through a procurement process ensuring that you’re provided with the best food and service. We also check that they comply with public liability insurance, food standards agency scoring (minimum 4 out of 5) and Fairtrade practice.

Do not use external suppliers. Your event may be cancelled and you will be liable for any costs incurred.

Approved caterers

BEats

BEats is a Bristol based street food collective. Their experienced traders can cater for the main event with street food from around the world.

Visit the BEats website

to view all the food traders they work with.

Brockley Stores

Brockley Stores is a farm shop based in Bristol. They bake, source and create food from local farmers, suppliers and producers. They can provide cold delivered food, as well as alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks.

Corks of Cotham

Corks of Cotham are an independent wine, spirit and beer merchant situated on Cotham Hill.

Double Puc

Double Puc offers a range of freshly made and responsibly sourced food and speciality coffee. They can provide cold breakfast or lunch options, as well as hot and cold drinks.

Elaine’s Kitchen

Elaine’s Kitchen are an event catering company catering, based in North Somerset. They offer cold buffets, hot and cold canapes, cakes and drinks.

Kate’s Kitchen

Kate’s Kitchen are motivated to create dynamic, seasonal, interesting and well-balanced menus. They can cater for any event, and offer a range of hot and cold food and drink.

Papa Johns

Papa Johns is an American pizza restaurant chain. They offer a range of delivered pizzas, sides and soft drinks.

Parsnip Mash

Parsnip Mash provide bespoke catering services from 50 to 500 guests. They offer delivered cold food, serviced hot and cold food and alcoholic drinks.

Ward’s Catering

Ward’s Catering offer a bespoke service and will individually plan each event tailoring the menu around your specific needs and budget. They can provide a selection of hot and cold breakfast items, hot and cold finger and fork buffets, canapes, popup and street food style catering, afternoon teas, and a wide range of drinks refreshments. They can also offer a fully stocked mobile bar service.

If you have any questions, contact

uob-catering@bristol.ac.uk

.
